statement.text: Corona phlebectatica is a fan-shaped pattern of small intradermal veins at the medial or lateral ankle, representing an early clinical sign of chronic venous insufficiency that correlates with venous reflux on duplex.

explanation.intuition: These are tiny blood vessels that form a distinctive fan or spray pattern around the ankle - like a small red/blue sunburst. They appear because the pressure from venous reflux backs up into the smallest vessels near the ankle bone.
explanation.key_insight: Corona phlebectatica is a highly specific sign of underlying venous reflux, present in 80-90% of patients with documented reflux. It often appears before more obvious signs of CVI and should prompt duplex evaluation.
explanation.technical_details: Location: medial or lateral malleolar region. Pattern: fan-shaped or parallel intradermal vessels. CEAP classification: C1 (telangiectasia). Clinical significance: indicates underlying reflux in 80-90% of cases, predicts progression to more severe CVI. Associated with: GSV reflux, perforator incompetence. Differential: spider veins without reflux (usually more scattered pattern).

clinical_features.appearance: Fan-shaped or sunburst pattern of intradermal vessels at ankle
clinical_features.significance: Indicates underlying venous reflux in 80-90% of patients
clinical_features.evaluation: Should prompt duplex ultrasound for reflux assessment

primary_sources.title: Journal of Vascular Surgery: Venous and Lymphatic Disorders

clinical_pearls: Fan-shaped pattern at ankle is highly specific for venous reflux
Present in 80-90% of patients with documented reflux
Should prompt duplex evaluation for underlying reflux
